trial_identification.studytitle: Intravenous midazolam-droperidol (combination), droperidol (only) or olanzapine (only) for the acutely agitated patient: A multi-centre, randomised, double-blind, controlled, clinical trial
trial_identification.scientifictitle: A randomised clinical trial to compare the efficacy of the intravenous midazolam-droperidol combination, droperidol only and olanzepine only for sedation of the severely agitated patient

interventions.interventions: Arm 1: Single intravenous bolus of midazolam (5mg) plus droperidol (5mg). Arm 2: Single intravenous bolus of dropridol (10mg) Arm 3: Single intravenous bolus of olanzapine (10mg)
interventions.comparator: The control treatment will be the midazolam-droperidol arm

primaryOutcome.outcome: Time to sedation as defined by a sedation score of less than or equal to 2 on a 6 point scale (6=highly agitated & violent, 0=asleep)

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Need for re-sedation <60 minutes after achieving sedation (rescue drug requirement). Resedation will be required if the patient again becomse acutely agitated and is a danger to themsleves of others.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: within 60 minutes of achieving adequate sedation initially

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Adverse events including airway obstruction, hypoventilation, oxygen desaturation (<90%), hypotension (<90mmHg), movement disorders (eg. dystonic reactions, twitching), seizures, vomiting or aspiration. All events are assessed clinically (observation) or with stadard equipment (sphygmomanometer, saturation probe)
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: within 60 minutes of achieving adequate sedation initially

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Emergency Department patients aged 18-65 years who require IV drug sedation for acute agitation
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: 1. known hypersensitivity or contraindication to the study drugs 2. reversible aetiology for agitation (hypotension, hypoxia, hypoglycaemia) 3. known pregnancy 4. acute alcohol withdrawal (particularly amenable to benzodiazepines alone)

trial_design.concealment: Patients requiring sedation will be determined by Emergency Physicians or Registrars. The next sequential study pack will be assigned to the patient. The study pack will contain the drugs randomly assigned to the patient. All drugs will be blinded.
